If you’re driven and willing to learn, you can build an amazing career here. There’s a strong team mindset across communities, supervisors, and regional managers. You’re heard, respected, and trusted to make decisions that impact the business. As an RFM, you manage important assets, large budgets, vendor relationships, and community needs, without being micromanaged. Camden provides everything you need to be successful. You never feel like you’re doing this job alone. Despite the workload, the company respects your personal life and supports flexibility when you need it. Quality, safety, compliance, and professionalism truly matter here. Your knowledge grows fast and consistently. The people here are supportive, genuine, and fun to work with. title: Grateful for a Long Career, but Culture Shifted in Recent Years
pros: • Camden is very technology-forward; systems and processes are streamlined and efficient. • Professional, collaborative work environment with many dedicated and talented team members. • Over my 33-year career, I met so many wonderful people and built lasting relationships. • Communities in the Tampa area are well-maintained and reflect strong operational standards. • The employee guest suite perk is one of the best benefits—affordable and far better than a hotel stay.
cons: • As a General Manager overseeing two communities in Tampa, it was difficult to consistently connect with all team members due to constantly moving between sites. • Compensation and benefits became less competitive. My new company offers more PTO in my first year than I received in 33 years with Camden, and a 40% rent discount compared to Camden’s 25%. • Since 2020, the company culture has shifted from personal and people-focused to more transactional. While Camden still promotes its “Have Fun” value through events, the underlying atmosphere has become tense, with a lack of genuine trust and connection. • I often felt like I could not rely on or trust my superiors, which made it difficult to feel supported or secure in decision-making. • Favoritism became more common—performance and experience were often overlooked in favor of those who played politics. • In the Tampa area alone, three out of four General Managers left within the last year, which speaks volumes.

title: Changed For The Worse
pros: Specifically, this review will be for anyone who is working on-site (managers, leasing agents, maintenance) and I'll start with the good here. When I first started with Camden it was great. Good pay/benefits, lots of opportunity for advancement, good people, residents and employees were treated well.. Support systems are great - you'll have someone to help cover all of your bases and aren't expected to do or know EVERYTHING (all budget responsibilities, contracts, invoicing, etc. for your property like other companies.) There is some beauty to this company (even still). Mainly, the people you work with day in and day out. These people are the reason you stay (even more so as a manager who hires them). I have a special place for all of my team members I've worked with over the years and will likely keep in touch with most of them.
cons: That said, a lot has changed over the years.... We removed simple amenities for the resident's enjoyment - just the little things! No more coffee downstairs, no more resident events, just to save money. Then we organized our structure which typically eliminated one manager position and one or more leasing agent PER PROPERTY - gone are the days where Leasing Agents can get promoted to Assistant Managers, AMs to CMs, so on so forth. There's just simply no opportunities available because the workforce was cut down so much. Why?? It saved the company over a million dollars a year. The result other than money savings? Employees are overworked and burnt out, residents are less confident and feel like we don't care as much anymore, and residents are really left out to dry in most scenarios - none of this money has been added to budgets and Operations funds continue to shrink year over year. Most of the money goes to Capital asset preservation funds (this is 100000% needed, don't get me wrong). That said, hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of ideas and plans get shut down every year because Camden dimply doesn't want to invest in resident satisfaction anymore. We're making sure our properties are ready to be bought by someone else, not improving the lives of our residents (Camden's alleged mission statement). Results also don't matter to upper management. It doesn't matter if you always meet or exceed goals year over year if you don't "drink the kool aid" in this politically based hierarchy. You have to fit the bill of the cult like personality/fake cheerleader image they want if you want to advance. I've seen multiple managers denied opportunities or lose out to lesser managers purely because the lesser manager doesn't fit the cheerleader bill. They're level headed, calm, and effective at their jobs and get punished for it. Versus, someone whose property has high turnover, is messy, misses budgets, BUT is over the top friendly (often times spending more time talking than doing actual work) and they go to EVERY company event. The overly friendly person who gets mediocre results gets the promotion over the better performer that is more even-keel and may miss events because life gets in the way. Lastly, to really nail home the point that good employees don't matter as much as money... I've seen multiple properties be sold. It's part of the business and it happens. However, when a property is sold and, inevitably, employees need to be let go, Camden decided to NOT retain the FANTASTIC employees who have years of experience and keep the ones that have been here for a fraction of the time, a fraction of the experience, and a fraction of the value. Why?? Yet again, MONEY. Get rid of the great employee who does everything right because they make $4 an hour more and keep the one that's still learning what left vs right is because they're cheaper. To summarize, their mission statement should be as follows "Guided by our values, we are committed to being the [most profitable] multifamily company by providing [mediocre living] to our customers [and maximizing value for our shareholders instead]."

title: Great Company, Terrible Department
pros: Contact center agents work from home which is convenient. The benefits are excellent and I feel the founders do care and try to show their employees that they are valued overall.
cons: Training: Training was inconsistent and unorganized, leaving you feeling unprepared to start the role. There are well over 30 “guides” you can pull for reference but in real time, during a call, it can be cumbersome as well as stressful trying to research when the conversation lengths and hold times are being monitored. There is also information and regular updates posted in Microsoft Teams regarding updates to guides which only makes it more difficult to locate information you may need as you have to check multiple avenues for the most up to date information. If you attempt to reach out for help as encouraged, via the “supervisor on call line”, you are made to feel like you are disturbing them and are incompetent for asking questions. Environment: The environment is incredibly micromanaged and your performance is intensely scrutinized. You are graded on 3 types of calls a month resulting in a performance grade for the service you provide. They also hop in and “live listen” to active calls, sometimes commenting in real time via Teams and distracting you from the task at hand. Email, text and chat templates are in place for you to utilize and the supervisors review every email you send. It feels at times they are looking for reasons to “coach” you. As an agent you do a little bit of everything and are held to the highest level of perfection while wearing multiple hats. You are yelled at, berated and degraded routinely by the callers and are regularly held accountable for mistakes that are not your own. If there is ever a time someone on site, at one of the properties reaches out pertaining to how you handled a situation, even when handled by the very specific guidelines that are put in place for you to follow, via the guides, the supervisors will almost always immediately side with them and imply the agent is incompetent and did not do their job correctly, only intensifying the feeling of being undervalued. In the event you ever have a bad day, or show the slightest indication that you are human or your demeanor in a call is seen as rude, you run the risk of being fired. This department has the highest turn over rate I’ve ever experienced at a company and if things continue this way, so will the turn over rate. Management: The management team initially gives the impression they are kind, supportive and open to feedback however this quickly changes once onboarding ends. As mentioned before, it feels uncomfortable reaching out for help however this is complicated by the extensive micromanagement and the fact that you are not allowed to make decisions based on your experience or without ensuring they will approve. Again, you have guides to reference however there are many instances where the situation is considered a grey area and again, you are not allowed to make decisions for yourself as there are rigid guidelines to be followed. While you are encouraged to be “transparent” and reach out if you ever do have concerns, the moment you do, you are gaslit and it’s implied you are the issue. You run the chance as being seen as problematic and unprofessional, even when bringing concrete examples for what your concerns are based on. There were multiple agents that were targeted and ultimately fired after they expressed issues they’ve had with the leadership, the work environment and/or training. Some even went to HR for assistance only to be met with the same end result. Unemployment. Culture: There are a lot of nice things the company generally does for its employees from holiday parties to employee appreciation day. The contact center specifically has customer service week and the supervisors have fun raffles for the department which is fun and very nice. They also send birthday and anniversary gifts which is also nice. It’s important to note that there is a severe imbalance of diversity in this department. There are 10 or 11 leaders in management and they are all Caucasian except for 1. There were multiple leaders that have left the department only to be replaced with more Caucasian leaders that had not been in the department as long nor performing as well as other agents, including agents of color. There have also been multiple agents of color that have left the department and/or company due to not being given the opportunity for growth after repeatedly requesting the opportunity for advancement. This is disappointing and disheartening to see. Compensation and benefits: The benefits and perks are excellent. The pay is just okay and due to the rising cost of living, it is barely enough to scrape by. New agents are making $6-$7 more than those with experience and tenure in the department which is discouraging. This department is 24/7 and Camden boasts itself on having 24/7 customer service for residents and prospects however the 24 hour option is put on the backs of only 6 overnight agents. The contact center never closes, so while you get paid for “paid” holidays, you do not get all of these days off like the rest of the entire company. Also if you work on any of the holidays, you do not get paid the standard, time and a half holiday pay for working on said holiday. There is also not premium pay for the overnight team. You are given a yearly bonus and raise however, they are distributed by agent preference and not by performance. A colleague and I received the same exact bonus and raise one year though I had been there a year longer and my performance numbers were much higher. When you attempt to discuss your compensation with leadership you are again hit with gaslighting and told it is not in the budget.
