Camden provides a fun and organized place to work, well compensated vacation pay, learning, development and mentoring programs are also available to all. Camden has a contact center available 24/7 that is run by Camden and it’s the best thing ever for us and our customers. I could go on and on but in the end I think you should apply now!
cons: I wish Camden could be in every state so that everyone could work for this company.

title: CAMDEN IS A GREAT PLACE TO WORK!!!!
pros: The benefits with Camden are amazing. Spectacular health care and vacation time. Employee guest suites through out the company. Management empowers you to actually make decisions and has the support to help you grow within the company.
cons: The only con I can think of is pay which is actually not that bad. We all (everyone not just Camden employees) would like to be paid more but Camden does a great job compensating its employees.

title: Company Values
pros: On paper, Camden Property Trust is a great company to work for. They are consistently in the Top Ten of Fortune's Best Places to Work list, and I suppose that may be true at the corporate and regional levels. If you enjoy unique perks such as vacation suites, company events, and sales meetings that are more like playtime, then Camden is absolutely a great company to work for. There is an immense sense of camaraderie amongst employees, even those that you don't work with on a daily basis such as team members from other properties, regional offices, and even the corporate office in Houston. You can truly make life long friends at Camden.
cons: In training, at ACE Awards, and at sales meetings and regional events, Camden places a high importance on the Camden Values, but in practice, it seems as though all of those are pushed aside in the name of instant profits and instant gratification of shareholders. The amount of work that you put in is not nearly on par with what the compensation is. Depending on the region that you're in, forget about upward mobility within the company. If positions do open up, they are filled by popularity and not by merit. Camden also made the list of best places to work for millennials, and I tend to think that it is because of all the unique perks and "have fun" company value, but if you're a millennial who is success driven, this is probably not a good fit for you.

title: Highly recommended
pros: You would be hard-pressed to find a more encouraging, supportive company culture. I have been with Camden for over 10 years and hope to be around for another decade. Employees are supported in both their personal and professional goals. Salaries and benefits are competitive, and our employee vacation units have come in handy for several family vacations.
cons: With a relatively small company and low turnover, it can take longer to move up. However, Camden makes sure that all employees can develop within their roles and position themselves for promotions when they are available; there is no wasted time here, only time spent learning and growing.

title: Amazing Company to work for!
pros: I love the environment Camden has created and am thankful everyday that I work for such a wonderful company with such amazing people. I am surrounded by positive energy and great mentors at every turn who are always willing to give advice and help with any questions I have. There is tons of room for growth and movement within the company, which you cannot find everywhere. Camden is a one-of-kind company and there is no place I would rather be!
cons: I get off work at 6pm, however I get to sleep in since we don't have to be at work until 9AM.

title: Camden is a GREAT place to work!
pros: Camden is a company where you can truly be yourself. Leadership is very focused on personal awareness and growth. This leads to high overall job satisfaction and is the reason many individuals stay in their positions for long periods of time.
cons: Very little job advancement opportunities as many people stay in their positions for long periods of time. Position advancement, many times, requires relocation to another city/state. This can be difficult for families with school aged children.

title: Mentally Draining
pros: Great benefits, that’s really about it

title: Camden is as good as the person standing in front of you
pros: * Excellent benefits. Insurance, 401k matching, employee stock purchase program, EAP, discounts, scholarships for children of employees, etc. A friend of mine left Camden (in a lateral move) to work for Greystar making about 5K more per year. Her insurance expenses more than doubled and ultimately took a pay cut. She also recognized the loss of value the company had on each employee. After a couple of years now, she is still surprised at the lack of interest in her personal contribution at Greystar and found that the grass was not greener, it wasn't even grass. * Camden's insurance is good, there are several options depending on your need, and I've never had an issue finding a good provider. * Competitive salaries in addition to really good benefits. (not just benefits, GOOD benefits) * Business practices and procedures are founded on experience, feedback and good Values. They listen to their employees at ALL levels. If front-line employees are disgruntled, unhappy or think their supervisor is unfair they provide hotlines and feedback avenues. HR doesn't take that sort of thing lightly and they don't ever take sides, they are fact-based, legal, moral and fair. * They want to be the best employer in addition to being the best multi-family (R.E.I.T.) housing provider. They work as hard to keep their employees happy as they do to keep their customers (renters) happy. The want to maintain the "Best Place to Work" designation so they seek feedback often and make changes based on the feedback. * Management is intuitive and often provides systems, support, or programs before the teams even know they need it.
cons: * Like any organization, they can have people in positions that can have a negative impact on fellow employees, customers and subordinates. I have been employed by at least four other multi-family organizations. None hold a candle to Camden's loyalty to their people and their customer. * The last two years have been more difficult than normal. Updates in software, hardware, systems and some practices have been more difficult to understand and deliver on-site. Employees at ANY other multi-family company would treasure and safeguard every effort Camden makes to support their teams. Employees at other companies and would roll their eyes at whining front-liners who sit online and write how bad the company instead of using one of the 11 ways they can DO something about it. * No matter what company you work for, or how much support the organization offers, there will be people who don't fully represent and execute Camden's Values, Brand and Promise. **Even though Camden blows other companies away and is driven to be an amazing employer, one person having a bad day, a bad life, or a bad attitude can interfere with their intentions. It's life. It's not a Con.

title: Heavy work load, but fun
pros: Out of the box work experience. Fun environment. Gives a format for employees to be heard via SoapBox. Allows employees to be who they really are.

We are in property management, therefore, managers need to be on property more. Not enough room for moving up. Implements too many programs and processes.

title: Better than others, but not the best

title: The Best Company I've Ever Worked For!
pros: Camden has an incredible company culture. Team members truly work together to provide service for residents and internal customers. There is a mentor program for new employees and lots of ongoing support. Camden truly cares about employees, residents, and communities.

title: It really is the best place to work

The culture is amazing. Everyone cares. Monday's do not suck. Before I contemplated being done with what I do. Camden has made work fun and exciting again. So glad I came on board.
cons: Luckily I have no cons.

title: Good company, property managers vary skills.
pros: They have great benefits and for starting pay they are high. Camden has a great training program at the district office for your first few days. No additional training outside of your first few days unless you sign up for it, but even then your community manager does have to approve it. Meaning you still might not get training. Incentives could be paid out at a higher rate considering how much money Camden brings in. The office technology is very outdated. You can apply for an open position but it is a good chance Camden already gave the job position to someone else, they just post it because it is policy to. You won't always hear back from sister properties' management about your application and you won't always get an interview. This goes against Camden's views on growth within the company. Not flexible with your schedule at all. Management refuses to help out or work on weekends. This causes 7-9 day stretches and still not hitting 40 hours due to the weekend hours. Part time no benefits.

title: A company that truly cares about their employees!

Everyone from the first day to now is supper nice and helpful!
cons: Have not found any yet!

Us Camdenites, are invested not only in the growth of our company but in the growth of our teams, peers, and ourselves. Camden truly is the best company to work for!

pros: Camden spends a lot of money training their employees to ensure that everyone is on the same page and that everything runs as a well oiled machine. The company values are wonderful and Camden has succeeded in making the list of best places to work year over year.

title: Leasing

title: Community Manager

title: Where are these positive reviews coming from?

title: Camden is the best!!!

title: Used to be better

title: Great place to work.
pros: There is an obvious family atmosphere and your team truly cares about your success and growth within the company.
cons: A lot of initiatives are thrown out with little to know preparation. This causes a lot of stress and adds to the already hefty workload.

title: Best work years of my life!
pros: Everything about this company is amazing. From the people, culture, structure, work ethic, teamwork, etc. I worked for this amazing company for 5 years! The only reason I left was because I was moving to an area that didn't have any Camden communities.
cons: I don't have anything bad to say. It can take some time to move up and that is the only downside.

title: Pure Magic
pros: Incredible culture Sense of family Access to all levels of leadership Ability to advance Leaders consider and implement new ideas from any employee Great recognition Encourage having fun
cons: This is a company where there are few cons. It is hard work and you will be challenged but if you are proactive about your own career development and are a positive individual you will succeed.

title: Camden leaders have values, integrity and are so good to their employees!
pros: It trickles down from the top - do the right thing, show respect, work with integrity, have fun and make people happy! As an employee of Camden for 10+ years, I am heard and valued; I have been given the tools to be successful being myself!
cons: If there ever is a "con," you are able to bring it up and discuss it in a safe place. I can't think of anything to describe here.

pros: Camden is by far the best company I have ever worked for. They truly care about you and your family. Great benefits,training and support. Customer focused and amazing culture. I have committed myself to a long term career with Camden.
cons: I have recruited 5 people to Camden. Cant say much negative about the company. Of course they are not perfect, but they have greatly increased my family's quality of life.

cons: ~If you get a weekend off, you then have to work at least 7 days in a row ~Only 10 days vacation to start ~You can never fully mentally check out of work because your team is still working when you are off

title: Extraordinary leadership

cons: Not a con really, but you must be interested in being a contributor at your best level.

title: Not good

title: Don't Believe the Hype

title: Great Place To Work

title: Smoke/Mirrors
pros: On boarding is exciting. You feel great to be a part of a different type of organization. An organization that cares.
cons: After onboarding you realize you’ve been blown a bunch of smoke. The culture died years ago and the proof is in the voluntary 40+ % of the company that turned over in the last 10 months. Many of these were long before the vaccine mandate. All this company cares about is money, nickel and diming customers, reputation, and their stock price. You will feel pressured early on in your employment and every time a Forbes survey comes out to share about the great and unique culture . (Email from CEOs/senior leaders on how important this is for our company). You will be told how much tenure is in this company. A lot of tenured employees chose to leave and the ones left will also tell you things aren’t the way they used to be. Upper management will ask you to spend your own money to save on expenses.. Micromanagement thrives here. You cannot speak up unless you want to be barred from any forward movement and I’ve seen many people blocked from great opportunities. If you’re looking to interview ask these questions and pay attention to the answers. - what did layoffs look like during covid? - why did 40% of the company leave Camden? - what are things that were done for employees and residents that don’t happen anymore and has the company benefited financially from the lack of those events. -what did Camden do for on-site employees during the pandemic in terms of labor? I’ll answer this one. Instead of closing offices for safety at the height of the pandemic they made us open our doors and extend working hours

title: Not what it used to be
pros: Benefits are good and the corporate suits are a plus.
cons: I worked with the company for 6 years. It used to be very customer focused. Our number 1 goal was to help ppl find a new home. At a time when ppl were losing their homes due to the economy we did whatever we could to help their transition into an apartment as comfortable as possible. I loved my job because I loved making my residents happy. A few years ago there was some major changes at corporate. It seemed at all the ppl that had been with the company were getting fired and all theses changes were happening. It turned from customet focused to money focused. No more waiving app fees or late fees. No exception!! My manager told us that every cent counts. She had me call a past resident from 2 years ago fort a $1 balance!!!! On top of that I couldn't except payment over the phone or online because it was such an old account it would not accept so I had to ask her to bring it in. On top of that we didn't accept cash either so I had to bring in a cashiers check! This was a resident who had lived with its for 7 years and who had written great reviews for us and then we put a bad taste in thier mouth over a $1!!!! Same manager had each of us employees make fake profiles on yelp in order to get great reviews so she would look good. We used to only chafe ppl for cleaning, paint and carpet shampoo. Only if resident really damaged something did we charged but that was rare. This manager made us charge for counter top replacements if there was little damage, Repaint ceilings , replace screens, replace blinds, tub reglaze, replace appliances. I'm pretty sure she just got promoted.

title: Don't expect to be accepted unless you drink the Kool Aid

cons: A previous review pretty much nailed it. This is a very cookie cutter environment. If you don't conform to the rest of the herd, you get pretty uncomfortable very quickly. People tend to be very cliquish and gossipy, and I saw so much conflict between Camden Values and the reality of how things worked, that I dreaded going in. Benefits are mediocre. Nothing to write home about, state of Texas offered better benefits as well as more time off. Perks are only good if you are able to use them-sometimes it is so hard to book a suite, there's just no sense in trying. The apartment discount was nice, but in order to live in a spot with decent schools you have to sacrifice your commute. Vacation and sick time are a joke and trying to find a healthy work/life balance is close to impossible. I love Ric, Keith, and Malcolm- I think they are fantastic people, but I also think that that they are going to have a hard time retaining talent if the perks and benefits aren't able to compete with the ever growing number of companies that are looking at how to do things outside the box.
